: Котельнич) is a small town in the western part of
. Most travelers will only see Kotelnich from the train when going along the
. Those who decide to stop by, though, may enjoy the sleepy town and the gorgeous paleontology museum that boasts skeletons of dinosaurs discovered in the nearby excavations.

First mentioned in chronicles in 1459, Kotelnich rapidly became a trade town renowned for its Alexeyevskaya Fair that was held for nearly 300 years until mid-19th century. In early 20th century, Kotelnich turns into a station of the Trans-Siberian railway and eventually becomes an important juncture where two branches of this railway (from Nizhny Novgorod and from Yaroslavl) meet.

The town is also famous for its excavations of dinosaurs on the banks of the Vyatka River.
Kotelnich has two train stations. The main hub,

, is located 1 km north of the town center. The ugly station building is more rewarding from inside; its abundant signposts are even translated into English. All local trains and most long-distance trains stop here. Check the

station is hardly used by anyone because it is located in the suburbs and served by infrequent local trains in the direction of Nizhny Novgorod, only.

Kotelnich is served by numerous long-distance trains that run along the
as well as Siberian destinations. Note, however, that some of the fast trains do not stop here. Travel time from

in the direction of Kirov depart every 2 hours and reach their destination in about 2 hours (compare to only 1–1.5 hours by long-distance trains). Other local trains are very infrequent and hardly useful for any travel.
Take any of the three roads: P157 from
(135 km), or an unnamed road from
is about 500 km along P159, either via Yaransk or via Sharya.

directions=embankment of the Vyatka River west of the town center

content=This cemetery church is in a sorry state. After deconsecration and years of oblivion, it is still used as a storage room and remains inaccessible to public. Peek around the fence to watch fine stone carvings adorning the walls and windows frames.

content=A small wooden chapel built in 2009 on the hill above the Vyatka River. It offers panoramic views over the river and railway bridge and, likewise, can be seen from the trains running along the Trans-Siberian route.
content=Regular city museum with few antiquities, some old furniture, and a big collection of stuffed animals. Nothing fancy.
directions=park area between Sovetskaya St. and Lenina St.

content=Following a recent initiative of the local government, this unkempt area was transformed into a decent park decorated with life-size dinosaurs (nothing to worry about, they are not alive... yet).

content=Two rooms of this small museum are literally brimmed with exhibits that were all excavated in Kotelnich. Enjoy benign dinosaurs and explore their history recorded in detail in the information boxes (Russian only). You can also experience everyday routine of a paleontologist by manipulating a brush and excavating a dinosaur in a box of sand. This simple procedure is thrilling for children and adults alike.

content=This neoclassical church was originally built between 1850 and 1900, deconsecrated after 1917, and reconsecrated in 2000's. Although the bell-tower vanished during the USSR period, the small white-blue building still looks pretty. Don't miss the adjacent library where decent copies of the destroyed Kotelnich churches are kept.

belong to different periods and styles. The typical 19th-century buildings can be seen in the town center along Sovetskaya, Lenina, and Oktyabrskaya streets. More rewarding, though, are minuscule Constructivist houses from 1920's. They were built after the big fire of 1926 that destroyed most wooden buildings in Kotelnich. Check the
(Алексеевская ярмарка) is a traditional event taking place annually on the last week of March.
is at the junction of Sovetskaya and Kirova streets.
where you get cheap salads and pelmeni, wash them down with several mugs of beer and polish everything with few shots of vodka. Not safe in the evening, though.
content=Good place for lunch, in the evening it seamlessly transforms into a noisy bar.
content=This unremarkable cafe gets fresh supplies from the local agricultural company.
directions=eastern end of the bypass road
content=It is basically a truck stop, but a good one.
content=This drab and shabby building is the only hotel in the town center. Most rooms share a single WC, as well as a shower that is charged extra. Few suites are also available, though. No food.
directions=eastern end of the bypass road
content=Nothing but a basic motel, though their cafe is quite good and worth visiting even if you don't stay for the night.
content=Unlike other Kotelnich hotels, this one gets some positive reviews on the web. Its cafeteria serves decent breakfasts and lunches.
— center of the region and a very interesting city with lots of old churches, gorgeous vernacular buildings, and fascinating museums
— dreary town boasting several old churches
